instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no image / backlight on internal display, but I have external image.

Already tried with known good display.

Client has droped a bit of coffe on it, and it has a bit of corrosion on L8420, and on <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> area.

Several test pads under <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT_F</SIGNAL> caps are burnt (gone), and I only have 12V on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT_F</SIGNAL> (not sure if it should that low).

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 3.288V

<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL>/SCL = 4.5V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
You should remove and resolder <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and other affected components.
Check all traces in that area.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hi,
I've removed <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and soldered again, and replaced L8420 with an 47 ohm resistor (0402), but I have the same result.

I think that on the first power on It showed the Apple logo for a sec, but then nothing else. Complete black image.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
"replaced L8420 with an 47 ohm resistor"
That is just a coil; why did you replace it with a resistor???
47 ohm is not its resistance for DC current!
You must get 0 ohm reading in ohm scale...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I've replaced L8420 with a 47 ohm resistor, because I don't have a donor board of the same model, either a coil to replace it, and it was the spec on the schematic (I thought it will do the job).

Can I replace it with a 0 ohm resistor?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
As I said, 47 ohm is not its resistance in DC current.
That is the resistance for AC current.
Use a tiny wire instead...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
The wire solved the problem.

TKS!
